meta.title: How Screen-Dependent Is Your Family?
meta.description: A judgment-free assessment of your family's relationship with screens — who reaches for them, when, and why. Based on validated instruments from pediatric and media psychology research.
meta.intro:
This isn't about counting hours or feeling guilty. Screens are a tool — every family uses them. What matters is the pattern: who reaches for them, when, and what happens when they're not available.

Answer for your family as it actually is, not as you wish it were.

sources.name: ScreenQ — Composite Measure of Screen-Based Media Use (Hutton et al., 2020)
SCREENS-Q — Socio-Ecological Screen Media Questionnaire (Klakk et al., 2020)
PSUS — Parent Screen-Based Device Use Survey (2023)
PMUM — Problematic Media Use Measure (Domoff et al., 2019)
MEPA-20 — Media Parenting Scale (Vacek et al., 2021)

questions.text: Picture your living room right now. How many screens could someone turn on without getting up from the couch?
questions.source: ScreenQ — device access domain: ambient device density is the strongest environmental predictor of total screen time

options.text: Zero — our screens live in closets, drawers, or other rooms until we deliberately set them up
One — a TV is there, but everything else is put away
Two or three — a TV, a tablet on the coffee table, maybe a laptop
Four or more — phones, tablets, a TV, a laptop — it's a screen buffet

questions.text: What happens at mealtime with screens in your family?
questions.source: SCREENS-Q — screen media environment domain: mealtime screen exposure is a key marker of ambient media saturation

options.text: All screens are off and away — meals are a screen-free zone and it's been that way long enough that nobody questions it
We aim for screen-free meals but the phone comes out sometimes — usually mine, if I'm being honest
The TV or a tablet is on during most meals — it keeps things calmer
Everyone — adults and kids — is looking at their own screen at the table

questions.text: Does your child have their own personal device — a tablet, phone, or laptop that's theirs?
questions.source: ScreenQ — device access domain: personal device ownership strongly predicts total daily screen hours

options.text: No personal devices — they use shared family ones, and only when a parent sets it up
They have a device, but it stays in a common area and gets put away between uses
They have their own device and mostly manage it themselves — it lives in their room or backpack
They have multiple personal devices and keep them nearby at all times
My child is too young for any of this — we don't really have kid-accessible devices yet

questions.text: Think about the last time you were making dinner with the kids underfoot. What role did screens play?
questions.source: PSUS — child care subscale: screens used to manage logistics of daily caregiving tasks

options.text: They played nearby, helped cook, or occupied themselves — screens didn't come into it
I offered a screen partway through because things were getting chaotic, but I tried other things first
I turned on a show before I even started cooking — it's the only way dinner gets made
I can't cook without a screen running for them — if I try, nothing gets done and everyone melts down

questions.text: Your child wakes up on a Saturday morning before you're ready to get up. What typically happens?
questions.source: PSUS — discipline and limit-setting subscales: morning routines reveal habitual screen deployment patterns

options.text: They read, play quietly, or come snuggle — screens aren't part of the morning routine
Sometimes they grab a device, sometimes they don't — it depends on the morning
They go straight for the tablet or TV — it's the understood deal so I can sleep a bit longer
The whole first hour of every morning is screen time — it's the only way anyone functions before breakfast
My child is too young to wake up and do anything independently

questions.text: Your child is having a rough transition — leaving the park, ending a playdate, getting in the car after school. How do screens factor in?
questions.source: PSUS — discipline and self-regulation subscales: screens as transition management tools

options.text: We use countdowns, warnings, or distraction with songs and conversation — screens don't enter the transition
I might promise screen time when we get home as motivation, but I don't hand one over in the moment
I pull out a phone or tablet to smooth over the protest — it stops the crying instantly
Every transition involves a screen — without one, leaving anywhere turns into a full meltdown

questions.text: If I asked your child what their three favorite shows or games are right now, would you know the answer?
questions.source: MEPA-20 — active mediation subscale: parental awareness of child media content

options.text: Yes — I could name them, describe what happens, and tell you why my child likes them
I'd get the names right, but I couldn't tell you much about the content
I'd guess at one or two, but new shows rotate in so fast I lose track
I genuinely have no idea what they're watching most of the time

questions.text: After your child watches something or plays a game on a device, does your family ever talk about it?
questions.subtext: Not policing — genuine conversation about what they saw or did.
questions.source: MEPA-20 — active mediation subscale: dialogic engagement transforms passive consumption into learning

options.text: Regularly — they tell me about plot twists, show me things they built, or we replay funny moments together
Sometimes — if they're excited about something they'll bring it up, and I try to engage when they do
Rarely — screen time ends and we move on to the next thing
Never — I don't really know what goes on during their screen time and they don't bring it up

questions.text: How does your family decide how long screen time lasts?
questions.source: MEPA-20 — restrictive mediation subscale: rule clarity around duration predicts child self-regulation around screens

options.text: There's a clear plan — a timer, a set number of episodes, or a consistent routine that everyone expects
We have a rough idea, but it often runs longer than planned — ending it takes negotiation
It usually goes until someone notices how long it's been or until the next activity forces it to stop
There isn't really an endpoint — screens run until bedtime or until the device dies

questions.text: You announce it's time to turn the screen off. What happens in your house?
questions.source: PMUM-SF — unsuccessful control and withdrawal items: transition off screens reveals dependence patterns

options.text: Minor grumbling at most — they move on to something else within a couple of minutes
Some protesting and stalling — 'one more episode!' — but they do eventually comply
It regularly escalates into crying, yelling, or a full negotiation battle
It's so unpleasant that I often just let it keep going rather than deal with the fallout

questions.text: Think about a recent weekend with decent weather. How much of the day involved screens versus other activities?
questions.source: PMUM-SF — tolerance and preoccupation items: weekend screen-to-activity ratio reveals displacement of alternatives

options.text: Screens were a small slice — most of the day was outside play, errands, projects, or hanging out together
A roughly even mix — some screen time, some active time, with natural breaks between
Screens filled most of the downtime — the non-screen parts were mainly obligations like meals and errands
Screens were basically the entire day unless we had somewhere specific to be

questions.text: Has anyone in your family — including you — ever said something like 'I should probably put this down' about their own device and then kept scrolling?
questions.subtext: This one's about the whole family, adults included.
questions.source: PMUM-SF — loss of control item; SCREENS-Q — parental media use domain: adult modeling of screen habits shapes family media culture

options.text: That doesn't really happen — when we're done with a device, we put it down
The adults get stuck sometimes, but the kids don't seem to have that problem yet
It happens regularly — at least one of us struggles to disengage from a screen on most days
Honestly, everyone in the house has trouble putting screens down — kids and adults alike

high.headline: Your home is set up well
high.detail: Devices aren't scattered everywhere, meals are largely screen-free, and personal device ownership is limited or managed. Your physical setup does a lot of the work — when screens aren't within arm's reach, the family naturally gravitates toward other activities. Research consistently finds that device accessibility is the single best predictor of how much a family uses screens, and yours is organized to support healthy habits without constant policing.
high.strength: Your home's physical layout and device management naturally limit screen time without requiring constant enforcement

medium.headline: Mostly contained, a few open doors
medium.detail: You've made some good structural choices — maybe screen-free meals are the norm, or devices live in shared spaces. That baseline matters more than you think. The areas to look at are the spots where screens are a bit too easy to reach: a tablet on the counter, a personal device with no designated parking spot, or background media that drifts on during quiet moments. One environmental tweak usually has more impact than a new rule.
medium.concern: Pick one accessibility gap — a device that lives out in the open, a room with too many screens — and create friction between your family and that screen for two weeks

low.headline: Screens are everywhere at once
low.detail: Devices are in every room, meals include screens, and there's little physical separation between your family and a glowing rectangle at any moment. This is incredibly common — screens are designed to be frictionless, and homes naturally drift toward saturation. The encouraging thing is that environmental changes are the single most effective intervention. You don't need more willpower or better rules. You need to physically move one device.
low.concern: Start with one physical change this week: designate a drawer or shelf as the device parking spot, or remove one screen from your most-used family room

high.headline: Multiple tools in your belt
high.detail: When the hard parenting moments hit — cooking with kids underfoot, rough transitions, early mornings — your family doesn't default to screens. You've got a range of strategies, and screens are one option among several rather than the automatic reflex. This doesn't mean you never use screens as a tool. It means they haven't become the only tool.
high.strength: Your family navigates the most common screen-trigger moments with a diverse set of strategies rather than reaching for devices by default

medium.headline: Some moments are handled, others trigger a screen
medium.detail: You manage some of the classic trigger moments without screens — maybe mornings are fine, or transitions aren't an issue. That flexibility is real and worth noticing. But there are specific moments where a screen has become the automatic play: cooking, car rides, or that window when everyone's patience is gone. Targeting the single most automatic one and trying a replacement even half the time is enough to break the reflex.
medium.concern: Identify your single most automatic screen-trigger moment and line up one alternative to try for just that situation this week

low.headline: Screens are doing the parenting heavy lifting
low.detail: Mornings, mealtimes, transitions, solo caregiving — in most of the hard moments, a screen is the first and sometimes only strategy. This isn't laziness. It means your family's routine has organized itself around screen availability, which happens gradually and without anyone deciding it. The useful realization is that most of this screen time is parent-initiated. That's actually easier to shift than child-driven demand, because you're the one making the call.
low.concern: Pick your easiest trigger moment — the one where you could most imagine trying something different — and experiment with just that one. Leave the harder moments alone for now.

high.headline: You know what's on the screen
high.detail: Your family's screen time includes real awareness: you know what your child watches, conversations happen around media content, and there are clear expectations about when screen time ends. Research draws a sharp line between guided and unguided screen use. Even at the same total hours, children whose parents are aware, engaged, and set consistent boundaries show better outcomes across cognitive and social development.
high.strength: Your awareness, engagement, and structure around screen content transforms your family's media time from passive consumption into something genuinely higher quality

medium.headline: Engaged in some ways, hands-off in others
medium.detail: You have a sense of what your child watches, or conversations about content happen sometimes, or screen time has some structure. That foundation puts you ahead of most families. The areas where things run more on autopilot — content you've lost track of, screen sessions with no clear endpoint, or media time that just flows into the next thing without a pause — are the spots where small increases in engagement make a real difference.
medium.concern: Try one engagement step this week: ask your child to show you their favorite thing from screen time, or set a simple end-point for the next viewing session

low.headline: Screen time is running unsupervised
low.detail: Your child is mostly navigating screens independently — choosing content, managing how long they watch, and consuming media without much adult awareness or involvement. When screens serve a childcare function, this is what naturally happens. The issue isn't screen time itself — it's that algorithm-driven, unsupervised viewing is consistently the lowest-quality type of screen use. You don't need to co-watch everything. You just need a window into what's happening.
low.concern: This week, sit with your child during screen time for just ten minutes — not to police, just to see what they're watching and ask them about it

high.headline: Your family can take or leave screens
high.detail: Turning screens off doesn't spark a crisis, weekends aren't organized around devices, and the adults in the house model healthy disengagement too. This adaptability is the clearest sign that screens haven't become emotionally or structurally necessary for your family. Research identifies this flexibility as the strongest protective factor against problematic use as children get older and screens become more compelling.
high.strength: Your family has genuine flexibility with screens — the strongest predictor of healthy media habits as your children grow

medium.headline: Attached but not stuck
medium.detail: Turning off screens provokes some friction, weekends include more screen time than you'd ideally want, and someone in the house — maybe a child, maybe you — has trouble putting a device down. This is where the vast majority of families live, and it's a workable place to be. The key signal to watch is whether the difficulty is stable or growing. If turning off screens is a bit harder this month than last, the pattern is drifting in a direction worth correcting.
medium.concern: Pay attention to whether screen-off transitions are getting harder over time — that gradual escalation is the thing to catch early, before it becomes the new normal

low.headline: Screens feel essential right now
low.detail: Ending screen time is a battle, weekends are dominated by devices, and the adults in the house may be struggling with their own screen habits too. When the whole family has difficulty disengaging, it signals that screens have become emotionally necessary — a regulation tool, an entertainment default, and a boredom filler all at once. The research on families who successfully pulled back is consistent: it takes about two weeks of restructured routine before the new pattern stops feeling like deprivation.
low.concern: The first two weeks of pulling back feel genuinely hard — but they get dramatically easier after that. Start with one screen-free window each day rather than trying to overhaul everything at once.

balanced.headline: Balanced Screen Ecology
balanced.subheadline: Your family has a healthy, flexible relationship with screens.
balanced.explanation: Screens are part of your family's life, but they're not organizing it. Devices aren't everywhere, you have multiple strategies for the hard parenting moments, someone knows what's on the screen, and everyone can unplug without it becoming a crisis. This doesn't mean perfection — it means screens are a genuine choice in your household, not a dependency.
nextSteps: Protect what's working — consistency over time matters more than perfection on any given day
As your kids grow, bring them into screen decisions: 'You get 30 minutes — do you want them now or after dinner?'
Check in every few months to see if screen time has quietly crept — habits drift, and that's normal as long as you notice
Watch your own device habits — kids model what they see, and your relationship with your phone matters
balanced.watchOutFor: Stressful stretches — illness, a new baby, a work crunch — will temporarily spike screen use for everyone. That's expected. What matters is whether your family returns to baseline afterward, not whether every week looks the same.
balanced.encouragement: You've built a family media culture where screens are genuinely optional. That kind of intentionality didn't happen by accident, and it will serve your family well as devices get more compelling in the years ahead.
balanced.comparativeContext: Research shows families in this range tend to have children who handle boredom well, transition off screens without extended conflict, and maintain a wide range of non-screen interests.
balanced.shareableSummary: Our family has a pretty healthy balance with screens — we're intentional about when and how they come out, and everyone can unplug without drama.

leaning.headline: Leaning on Screens
leaning.subheadline: Screens are playing a bigger role than you probably planned — and it's worth looking at where.
leaning.explanation: Your family uses screens regularly, and they've quietly become the default for more situations than anyone consciously decided. The domain breakdown below shows you where the lean is heaviest — maybe devices are too accessible, maybe screens have become your go-to for the hard parenting moments, or maybe ending screen time is getting harder. Knowing where the weight falls tells you where one targeted change will make the biggest difference.
nextSteps: Look at your domain breakdown and pick the lowest-scoring area — make ONE change there and stick with it for two weeks
If Device Access is low: move one device to a less convenient spot or create one screen-free zone
If Parenting Triggers is low: identify the one moment you most reliably reach for a screen and line up a single alternative
If Screen Resilience is low: try one screen-free evening this week — just dinner to bedtime, nothing dramatic
leaning.watchOutFor: The temptation is to overhaul everything at once. Don't. Pick one domain, make one adjustment, and live with it for two weeks. Trying to change four things simultaneously usually means nothing sticks.
leaning.encouragement: You're in the zone where small, targeted changes make the biggest difference. A month from now this can look completely different — not through a revolution, but through one or two adjustments in the right spot.
leaning.comparativeContext: Most families score in this range. Research shows that one or two targeted environmental changes — like a screen-free mealtime or moving a device — typically shift family screen patterns within two to three weeks.
leaning.shareableSummary: We're leaning on screens a bit more than we'd like — time to pick one thing to adjust and see what shifts.
leaning.retakeAdvice: Retake in 4-6 weeks after making one targeted change

heavy.headline: Screen-Heavy Household
heavy.subheadline: Screens are doing a lot of heavy lifting in your family right now.
heavy.explanation: Devices are everywhere and always on, screens are the go-to for hard moments and downtime, much of the viewing runs without guidance, and unplugging feels like it would cause a meltdown. This isn't about addiction or bad parenting — it's about your whole family's routines having gradually organized around screens. The domain breakdown below shows exactly where the weight is, and the research is clear: families who make targeted environmental changes see real shifts within two to three weeks.
nextSteps: Start with the ENVIRONMENT, not rules: move one device, create one screen-free zone, or establish one unplugged meal
Pick your easiest win from the domain breakdown — whichever area feels most changeable right now
Expect one to two hard weeks when you first change things — that's the adjustment period, not proof it's failing
Look at your own screen habits too — the research is clear that family-wide changes stick better than rules that only apply to kids
heavy.watchOutFor: If reducing screen time causes extreme, prolonged meltdowns daily for more than two weeks, talk to your pediatrician. Sometimes intense screen dependence signals underlying regulation challenges that deserve professional attention.
heavy.encouragement: You're here reading this, which means you're questioning the pattern. That awareness is genuinely the hardest step. Research on families who successfully pulled back shows one consistent finding: they didn't do it all at once. They changed one thing, stuck with it, then changed one more.
heavy.comparativeContext: Research shows that even families with very high screen use can shift to balanced patterns within two to three months of consistent environmental changes. The first two weeks are the hardest — it gets markedly easier after that.
heavy.shareableSummary: Screens have quietly taken over more of our family's day than we realized — time to start making changes, one small step at a time.
heavy.retakeAdvice: Retake in 6-8 weeks after making one or two environmental changes
